source:
You can assign and remove Drupal user roles based on the user groups given to the user in Keycloak. The Keycloak user's groups will be retrieved using the UserInfo endpoint of your realm.
Before using this feature, you need to map group memberships to the userinfo within the mappers section of your Keycloak client settings.
Add user role @role to @user, as evaluation "@operation @pattern" matches @groups.
Adds language parameters to Keycloak authentication requests and maps OpenID connect language tags to Drupal languages.

Allows limiting the nesting level of split group paths. E.g. the group path "/Internal/Public Relations/Social Media" with a group path nesting limit of "1" will split the group path into "Internal" only, a group path nesting limit of "2" will return "Internal" and "Public Relations", and so on. A value of "0" will not limit nesting and return all groups.

Allows splitting group paths into single group names. If enabled, Keycloak group paths will be splitted using the "/" character and every path segment will be treated as single user group name. E.g. the group path "/Internal/Public Relations" will be split into the groups "Internal" and "Public Relations", and the mapping rules will be applied to both groups. Please note: If this option is enabled, using "/" within any group name may have unintended side effects.

Changes Drupal's authentication back-end to use Keycloak by default. Drupal's user login and registration pages will redirect to Keycloak. Existing users will be able to login using their Drupal credentials at /keycloak/login.

Depending on the version of KeyCloak used a specific localization parameter may need to be used. Select between the choices given. The default is kc_locale, but if you find your system is not behaving the way you expect it with multilingual setups, cross-reference the API documentation, you may need to use ui_locale instead.
Domains that are allowed to initiate SSO using ISS
During login and user registration you can synchronize user attributes with OpenID claims using the OpenID Connect module's claim mapping.
Enables OpenID Connect Keycloak sign on and user data synchronization.
Enables assigning Drupal user roles based on Keycloak group name patterns.
If email address has been changed for existing user, save the new value to the user profile.
If the user's email address changed in Keycloak, you can synchronize this change with the Drupal user's email address.
If your Keycloak is using different locale codes than Drupal (e.g. "zh-CN" in Keycloak vs. "zh-hans" in Drupal), define the Keycloak language codes here that match your Drupal setup.
Login to Drupal using Keycloak OpenID Connect
Name of the user groups claim. This can be a fully qualified name like "additional.groups". In this case, the user groups will be taken from the nested "groups" attribute of the "additional" claim.
Optionally end a user's Keycloak session, when logging out from Drupal, or automatically log out from Drupal when the Keycloak session ends.
Optionally replace Drupal's authentication back-end entirely with Keycloak.
Remove user role @role from @user, as evaluation "@operation @pattern" matches @groups.
Replace Drupal login with Keycloak single sign-on
Replace Drupal login with Keycloak single sign-on (SSO)
Synchronize email address changes from within Keycloak
Synchronize user fields with OpenID claims

The Keycloak module allows you to authenticate your users against a Keycloak authentication server. You can enable the Keycloak client within the OpenID Connect settings page. For more information, see the online documentation for the Keycloak module.
The base URL of your Keycloak server. Typically https://example.com[:PORT]/auth.
The e-mail address is already taken: @email
The e-mail address is not valid: @email
Update email address in user profile
Use Keycloak as Drupal authentication back-end

When using a multi-language Drupal site and a multi-language Keycloak authentication server, you can forward language parameters to the login and register pages and map Keycloak locales to the Drupal user's language settings.
Whether to log out of Drupal, when the user ends its Keycloak session.
Whether to sign out of Keycloak, when the user logs out of Drupal.
You can now enable Keycloak OpenID Connect sign in at the OpenID Connect settings page.
Your Drupal users can use an external Keycloak authentication server to register and login to your Drupal site.
